docs.lead_paragraph: For my 40th birthday, my friend Jo-Ann gave me a T-shirt that proclaimed ''Still perfect . . . after all these years!'' For my 50th birthday, my friend Jane insisted that I wear a button announcing ''50 . . . The Legend Lives On.'' And last week in honor of my 60th, Jane wrote a song in which she called me ''a high-octane goddess.'' Well, a goddess I'm not, but after a vigorous celebratory weekend of hiking and rock-climbing I would not dispute the high-octane attribute. I must be doing something right. For those who wish to preserve youthful energy and enthusiasm, I'll share the steps that got me through the sixth decade more or less intact and that I hope will carry me through the next three.

headline.main: Secrets of Keeping Aging's Effects at Bay

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column offers advise on preserving youthful energy and enthusiasm despite mechanical infirmities associated with advancing age; cites importance of regular exercise and proper nutrition in slowing biological aging (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Like thousands of children with Type 1 diabetes, Shannon Meng gets injections of insulin every day. But unlike them, Shannon does not have diabetes. In fact, she is perfectly healthy. Shannon, a 10-year-old from Ramona, Calif., is one of about 600 volunteers, from age 3 to 45, participating in a diabetes prevention trial, sponsored by the National Institutes of Health.

headline.main: Trying to Stop Diabetes Before It Starts

docs.abstract: Some 600 children and adults who have close relative with diabetes take part in National Institutes of Health-sponsored trial to determine whether daily treatment with low doses of insulin can prevent onset of Type 1 diabetes; study tests theory that tiny amounts of insulin will acclimate body and prevent immune system from attacking insulin-producing cells in pancreas; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Grappling with feelings of loss and abandonment now that ''The Sopranos'' has been snatched away from your Sunday nights? Nothing to be ashamed of here. Your therapist, should you consult one, may be enduring the same grief. Psychologists and psychiatrists around the country -- especially the psychoanalytically inclined -- have been watching the HBO series, which just ended its third season, with an almost cultish devotion.

headline.main: Therapists Reveal Their New Obsession: 'The Sopranos'

docs.abstract: Psychologists and psychiatrists around nation have been watching HBO series The Sopranos with almost cultish devotion; laud portrayal of therapy sessions of show's main character, Mafia boss plagued by panic attacks; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: There's the war on cancer, and there's the war over cancer -- or what the cancer cognoscenti call ''oncopolitics,'' the high-stakes competition over money, medicine and policy. And no one has a better time stirring the pot than Paul Goldberg, a writer, who with his wife, Kirsten Boyd Goldberg, produces The Cancer Letter, a newsletter based in Washington that keeps a muckraker's eye on cancer's power elite.

headline.main: Newsletter Trains Muckraking Eye on Cancer World

docs.abstract: Interview with writer Paul Goldberg and wife, Kirsten Boyd Goldberg, publishers of Cancer Letter, newsletter that examines high-stakes competition over money, medicine and policy; newsletter's several thousand readers include leading cancer researchers, activists and policy makers; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The emotional aspects of retirement are proving to be vastly more complex than previously thought, according to recent social science research. With changes in the work force, researchers are now focusing more on women and are examining how retirement affects couples' relationships. ''Retirement has long been seen as an individual -- mainly a male -- passage, but increasingly couples must deal with two retirements,'' said Dr. Phyllis Moen, a professor of sociology and human development at Cornell University and the lead author of a study on couples' retirement transitions, published in the spring issue of Social Psychology Quarterly.

headline.main: New Portrait Of Retiring Is Emerging

docs.abstract: Recent social science research shows emotional aspects of retirement are vastly more complex than previously thought; researchers are now focusing more on women and examining how retirement affects couples' relationships; Dr Phyllis Moen's study found that retirement is happy time for couples but that first two years after leaving job is period of marital strife (M)
